title: Girl, 17, dies from mumps while on holiday with family in Majorca
text:
Molly Patterson, 17, began feeling ill while on holiday in Majorca (Picture: North News / NNP)

The family of a teenager who died of suspected mumps in Majorca have questioned why doctors didn’t send her to hospital.

Molly Patterson, 17, had been away with her auntie, uncle, cousins and friends when she fell ill at the start of the week.

By the following Friday her condition had worsened, and a doctor who was called out to see her gave her paracetamol and ibuprofen.

But later that night the teen’s eyes rolled backwards and she died on October 11 after paramedics attended the scene for more than two hours.

Molly’s mother Danielle Bower, 37, said: ‘I can’t comprehend it. It’s just not real. Molly has all her injections, she had everything when she was a baby.

She had been away with her auntie, uncle and friends (Picture: North News / NNP)

‘We don’t know anything for definite about why she died. We haven’t had the coroner in, she’s still abroad. I’m absolutely heartbroken. She shouldn’t be by herself.

‘Molly was an angel. She was funny, gorgeous, witty. She was the life of the party [and] so well loved. She was brilliant.’

According to the NHS website, two does of the MMR vaccine against measles, mumps, and rubella, both given to children before the age of four, provides 95 per cent immunity against the infection.

Molly’s family say she was also treated for tonsillitis two weeks before she went on holiday, which may have made her vulnerable to falling ill.

Dominique Bower, 34, Molly’s aunt, said the teenager had started throwing up on Wednesday at a water-park they attended together.

Molly’s family say she was vaccinated as a baby (Picture: Facebook)

By Friday morning she was delirious and an on-site doctor examined her around her neck and indicated to the family it was mumps.

Molly was struggling to breathe, but after taking painkillers she fell asleep, with her friend Niamh taking care of her while the others went to the pool.

Dominique said: ‘We came back up to her room and she had been sick all over herself. We put her in the bath and washed her hair.

‘Then we wrapped her in a towel and [her uncle] Dylan scooped her up like a baby. Her friend was combing her hair and then all I heard was screaming.

‘Her eyes had rolled back. From 5:25pm right on, the paramedics and doctors worked on her for over two hours.

The doctors diagnosed her with mumps (Picture: North News / NNP)

‘I looked at Molly like a daughter. She was a beautiful niece, I just wish I could bring her back. She’ll always have a place in our heart.’

The family landed back in the UK on Monday October 14, but Molly’s body is still in a mortuary in Inca, Majorca.

A GoFundMe page has now raised more than £9,700 to bring the teen home to be buried in Sherburn Hill, County Durham.

But Molly’s grandmother Tracey Lawson, 59, said the family are desperate for answers.

She said: ‘At the moment there’s not a lot to say because she’s not here. Why did she die? That’s what we’ve got to ask.

‘Why didn’t that doctor send her to the hospital? We have a lot of questions and no answers.’

description: Molly Patterson, 17, was on holiday in Majorca when she fell ill with the mumps, despite being vaccinated as a child.
